Authors: Mariana Del Olmo Ruiz, A. Elizabeth Arnold
Title:
Multi-locus phylogenetic analyses reveal cryptic species
among endophytic and endolichenic Lecythophora
Keywords:
phylogenetic species, species boundaries, fungal
diversity, Coniochaeta, antagonism
Abstract:
Lecythophora (teleomorph Coniochaeta) is an anamorphic
genus of filamentous Ascomycota in which species boundaries are
difficult to delimit based on morphological characters alone. The genus
is particularly interesting because some species can cause opportunistic
human infections, produce novel secondary metabolites and inhibit plant
pathogenic bacteria and fungi. Here we assess the phylogenetic and
morphological species boundaries and the capacity to antagonize
particular plant pathogenic fungi in thirty-three endophytic and
endolichenic Lecythophora strains, along with ex-types of the six
described species of Lecythophora. We found that most of the
Lecythophora strains had the capacity to inhibit growth in two plant
pathogenic fungi but their species boundaries based on morphological
characters are not well defined, making them difficult to recognize and
allowing misidentifications. Multi-loci analyses recognized at least ten
phylogenetic species, seven of which are new to science, and suggested
that three currently recognized species should be collapsed into a
single species. Recognition of cryptic species and characterization of
novel biodiversity among endophytic and endolichenic strains, which are
cryptic in nature, has major implications in our estimation of fungal
diversity.
